SP.P: Ah, my dear friend, have I found you at last?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Stur.
SP.P: Oh, the sight of you rejoices my heart. But I have lost my dear girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Dash.
SP.P: And I have found your dear girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Stur.
SP.P: What do you tell me?

SP.SPEAKER: Dash.
SP.P: Nothing but truth: she is safe, and I am safe, and all is right; but you brought me into a pretty scrape—I was very near getting a niche in the Book of Martyrs, by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Stur.
SP.P: Hey!

SP.SPEAKER: Dash.
SP.P: Nay, this is no time to dwell on past perils.—Jaquelina impatiently expects you; so make haste to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Stur.
SP.P: But this lady needs protection.

SP.SPEAKER: Dash.
SP.P: Mine is devoted to her. There is one of my servants; he will conduct you to your mistress, while this lady may command from me whatever ser∣vice she requires. So, without ceremony, fly as fast as your worn-out frame will suffer you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Sir, do not let me tax your kindness, nor dull your joy with my misfortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Dash.
SP.P: Madam, happiness never found entrance in that breast which was not open to the sorrows of a lovely woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: You are truly generous; but indeed it grieves me much to trespass thus. You are bur∣dened with a being whose mind is rent with agony, and whose frame is enfeebled with fatigue and anguish.

SP.SPEAKER: Dash.
SP.P: Take comfort, Madam, and hope for hap∣piness; lean on my arm, and let me conduct you to safety and repose.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: I am bound to you for ever. (She leans on him, and as they are going Alphonso enters.)

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.P:
Horror! 'tis he! Such a sight would brace the arm of palsied cowardice, and in the breast of mercy's self infuse a tiger's fury. Match∣less extent of woman's perfidy! a few hours past, with all the seeming of unshaken constancy, wert
thou not kneeling at my feet, adjuring Heaven to witness for thy innocence? and now my eyes be∣hold thee in the arms of thy cursed paramour! Villain! I thought my sword had long since paid the debt I owed thee: I'll now make justice cer∣tain—and first to deal it here;—false woman, die! (Rushes at Angelina, who faints, and is supported by Dashington, he defending her with his sword. Sir Sturdy enters, and runs between them: he is followed by Leonora and Jaquelina.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Stur.
SP.P: I thought this wild-looking gentleman would be falling foul of somebody. Sir, if you don't curb your passions, you may depend on it they will injure your health.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Heavens! my sister!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: My dearest Leonora!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: But whence this fury and distraction? How altered are your husband's looks!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Altered, indeed, my sister! some dreadful error has possession of his mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.P: Error! Oh, shameless woman! Can it be error now? there stands the author and pro∣claimer of your infamy.

SP.SPEAKER: Dash.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Heaven can witness for me, that till this hour I ne'er beheld his face.

SP.SPEAKER: Dash.
SP.P: Give me leave, Sir, to say, that you are a most incomprehensible gentleman. I am ready to admit, that on a certain stormy day, when you and I were weather-bound, I was more communica∣tive than I ought to have been to a stranger; but may devils fly away with me in reality, if I ever mentioned to you that lady's name (which even yet I have not the honour of knowing); I only named to you the Lady Angelina d'Esparza.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.P: And who but she is owner of that name?

SP.SPEAKER: Dash.
SP.P:
Why, that lady, is n't she? (Pointing to
Leonora.) Pray, Ma'am, is n't your name Ange∣lina d'Esparza?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: No; that is my sister's name, the wife of Don Alphonso.

SP.SPEAKER: Dash.
SP.P: Whew! here is a business! Am I really awake, or is this all a dream? Did I, or did I not, see you at Madrid?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: You did; while I was on a visit to my sister, during Don Alphonso's absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Dash.
SP.P: And—Lord, I begin to find that I have made a cursed deal of mischief. The house, Ma∣dam, where you did me the honour to receive me, and allow me to express my passion, was—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: My sister's; and to my shame I own, from apprehension that she would disapprove my con∣duct, it was without her knowledge I received you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dash.
SP.P: (To Angelina.) My dear Ma'am, I beg you a million of pardons; and, my dear Sir, not∣withstanding you made a lunge clean through me, I confess you have great reason to be offended: but you see it was all a mistake.

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.P: But whence could this mistake arise? Leonora would never, surely, in her sister's name, receive the visits of a lover!

SP.SPEAKER: Dash.
SP.P: No, Sir; she admitted my visits under no name at all, and obliged me too to promise not to make inquiries. Her commands I punctually obeyed; but at our last interview, as I was quitting the house, I heard a passer-by exclaim, "There lives the beauteous Angelina d'Esparza!" I there∣fore naturally concluded that the beauteous Ange∣lina was this lady. (To Leonora.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Stur.
SP.P: What a blunder! and it is most ex∣traordinary, that, though there is an Irishman among you, he has had no hand in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Alphonso!

SP.SPEAKER: Alph.
SP.P: Oh, forgive me, dearest Angelina!

SP.SPEAKER: Dash.
SP.P: Although I confess myself horribly to blame, I must say, Ma'am, (To Angelina.) that husband of yours is as hasty a gentleman as ever jerked a sword out of its scabbard. The moment I mentioned the name, out came that damned long toledo, and in three seconds it was through me. Upon my soul the greatest blame is due to your rashness.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: No, to your tattling.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Stur.
SP.P: Ah, that is a devil of a fault: never kiss and tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mig.
SP.P: So I have found you out at last, and I am happy to tell you, that those desperate ruffians whom you (To Dashington.) hindered from cutting our throats, are all in safe custody. But what do you stay here so long for? There is a devilish good dinner ready; so come in, and be jolly.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: We have discovered the error, Sir, which led us to suppose that this gentleman had encoun∣tered your son.

SP.SPEAKER: Mig.
SP.P: Why, I was sure it must turn out a mis∣take; for I have it under my son's own hand that he is at Lima, and intends to remain there; and I am not sorry to find that he has taken himself a wife, since you wish to take another man for your husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Dash.
SP.P: And may I hope, Sir, that you will con∣sent to my marriage with your ward?

SP.SPEAKER: Mig.
SP.P: I consent, with all my soul! She is to be married, not I; and, therefore, I don't see that my inclination has any thing to do but to fol∣low hers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Stur.
SP.P: Ah, my sweet Jaquelina! if your fa∣ther would think in this manner, it would be the saving of my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Jaq.
SP.P: And of mine too.

SP.SPEAKER: Mig.
SP.P: Would it? Why, then, I have the satis∣faction of telling you that her father is now per∣fectly disposed to let her please herself. He only placed her in a convent till he had informed him∣self thoroughly of your character and fortune; with both which he is now perfectly satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Stur.
SP.P: Then I am the happiest man living.

SP.SPEAKER: Dash.
SP.P: What, with such a catalogue of mala∣dies!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Stur.
SP.P: Love has cured them all, and I feel at this moment that I am as stout a man as ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Mig.
SP.P: If you are not—Hercules must have been a shrimp to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Now, my dear Guardy, I have but one favour to ask, which is, that you will relinquish your office, and cease to be an Inquisitor.

SP.SPEAKER: Mig.
SP.P: To that I can't consent; for I am not sure that any other person holding my office would do so little mischief as myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Dash.
SP.P: Yours is the system of true philanthropy—Not to be contented with simply doing good, but also to labour to prevent the evil designs of others—not only to practise virtue, but to pre∣serve the helpless from virtue's foes.

LG.L: From sorrow and perils tormenting,
Since now we are happily free,
Our pleasure in harmony venting,
Let's pour forth the numbers of glee.
So merrily, merrily singing;
Let joy's sprightly sound
Be wafted around,
While the bells are so merrily ringing.
What transport! misfortunes ideal,
And springing from error to find!
And those transports will all become real,
If you to our errors prove kind.
